title: 106_hr4465
content:
The "Fairness in Textile Trade Act of 2000" aims to equalize trade in textile and apparel goods between the United States and WTO member countries. The "Fairness in Textile Trade Act of 2000" sets the policy for the United States to negotiate reciprocal market access in textile and apparel goods within the WTO. The President must determine if each WTO member country provides similar market access for US textile and apparel goods. If access is less favorable, the President will impose measures. The "Fairness in Textile Trade Act of 2000" requires the President to impose quotas, tariffs, or other measures on textile and apparel products of countries that do not provide similar market access for US goods. The President must negotiate agreements to remove trade barriers, and adjust measures if agreements are reached. The President must report actions taken to Congress annually. The President is required to report annually on actions taken under the "Fairness in Textile Trade Act of 2000," including determinations, measures implemented, negotiations, and adjustments made. The report must include the rationale for each action. Definitions for "WTO" and "WTO member country" are provided in the Act. SEC. 3. Civil actions for damages arising from fraudulent acts of importers allow producers, distributors, or retailers of textile or apparel goods to bring a civil action in Federal court against violators for damages incurred. The burden of proof is on the plaintiff to establish the violation by a preponderance of the evidence. The remedy provided by this section is exclusive if damages have been recovered under any other law for the same violation.

SEC. 4. Extension of benefit period for trade readjustment allowances for adversely affected workers enrolled in training programs. SEC. 5. Amendment to the Trade Act of 1974 extends benefit period to 52 weeks. Individuals receiving trade adjustment assistance can receive credit for health insurance premiums paid. SEC. 25B addresses health insurance costs for individuals receiving trade adjustment assistance. Individuals receiving trade adjustment assistance can claim a tax credit for 50% of the amount paid for qualified health insurance for themselves, their spouse, and dependents. Qualified health insurance excludes coverage from employer or group health plans. Trade adjustment assistance refers to aid provided under specific programs. The term 'trade adjustment assistance' refers to aid provided under specific programs in the Trade Act of 1974. Special rules apply, including coordination with other deductions and denial of credit to dependents. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections for subpart A part IV of the Code. Trade Adjustment Assistance for textile and apparel workers allows for benefits in cases of employment termination due to decreased sales or plant closure. The Secretary of Labor must certify eligibility within 30 days of a petition. Effective date for health insurance cost assistance is after December 31, 2000.
